questions.text: Which nerve is most likely affected, based on the hand posture shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows Claw hand deformity wherein the MCP joint of the fingers is hyperextended while the IP joint is flexed in the 4 th and 5 th digits. This occurs due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand which are supplied by the ulnar nerve. Thus, ulnar nerve palsies lead to claw hand deformity.
  • ➤ The given image shows Claw hand deformity wherein the MCP joint of the fingers is hyperextended while the IP joint is flexed in the 4 th and 5 th digits.
  • ➤ This occurs due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand which are supplied by the ulnar nerve.
  • ➤ Thus, ulnar nerve palsies lead to claw hand deformity.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10 tablets of paracetamol. He has developed oliguria and LFTs are deranged. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. N-acetylcysteine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the event of paracetamol toxicity, the antidote of choice is N-acetylcysteine, which should be administered as soon as possible to mitigate liver damage and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A patient presented with tingling and numbness in the legs, polyuria, and weight loss. He underwent a bone marrow aspirate (image as shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.correct_answer: C. Multiple myeloma with renal involvement
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple myeloma is identified by an increase in clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow, accompanied by systemic symptoms such as renal involvement, neuropathy, and weight loss.

questions.text: A child was diagnosed to have CFTR gene mutations. What is the defective channel? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cl

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mutations in the CFTR gene lead to defective chloride channels, which are responsible for the thick, sticky mucus characteristic of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: Which defect is shown below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Homonymous hemianopia is characterized by the loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes and is typically caused by lesions in the contralateral optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe.

questions.text: A young male patient, aged 20, presents with increasing localized pain that developed gradually over time. Imaging via X-ray revealed sunray appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Osteosarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone cancer, and it often presents in adolescents and young adults (like this 20-year-old patient). A "sunray appearance" on X-ray is a classic sign of osteosarcoma, where bony spicules radiate outward from the tumor.
  • ➤ Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone cancer, and it often presents in adolescents and young adults (like this 20-year-old patient).
  • ➤ A "sunray appearance" on X-ray is a classic sign of osteosarcoma, where bony spicules radiate outward from the tumor.

questions.text: A young male presents to surgery OPD with a verrucous lesion over the penis as shown in the image. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the management of choice in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence. This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.
  • ➤ Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence.
  • ➤ This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.

questions.text: 15-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura. CRP and ESR were elevated, and urinalysis showed RBCs. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IgA vasculitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura) commonly presents with palpable purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain, and renal involvement, and is characterized by IgA immune complex deposition.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia, who did not respond to haloperidol and thioridazine, was started on drug A. After beginning treatment with drug A, the patient's psychotic symptoms improved; however, he developed sialorrhea, dyslipidemia, weight gain, and hyperglycemia. Which drug is most likely to be 'drug A'? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clozapine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the treatment of treatment-resistant schizophrenia, Clozapine is often effective where other antipsychotics have failed. However, its use is associated with notable side effects including sialorrhea, significant weight gain, dyslipidemia, and hyperglycemia.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 222-224.

questions.text: A woman suffered from sunburn after enjoying a vacation on a beach. Now while taking a shower lukewarm water (40 degree celsiuis) touches her back causing her to feel pain. What type of receptors are activated by lukewarm water and what causes her to feel pain? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Innocuous thermal receptor - allodynia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allodynia is a condition where a normally non-painful stimulus, such as lukewarm water, causes pain. This occurs due to the activation of innocuous thermal receptors in the setting of heightened skin sensitivity, such as after a sunburn.
  • ➤ Allodynia

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Congenital rubella syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The triad of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), cataract, and sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).

questions.text: Which tongue papillae do not have taste buds? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Filiform

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The filiform papillae do not contain taste buds and are primarily involved in general sensations like touch and texture, not in the sensation of taste

questions.text: Why do neoplastic cells utilize Warburg metabolism? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases glucose utilization by neoplastic cells

options.label: B
options.text: It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication

options.label: C
options.text: It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production

options.label: D
options.text: It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer cells immortal

questions.correct_answer: B. It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neoplastic cells utilize the Warburg metabolism to generate metabolic intermediates necessary for cell growth and multiplication. Despite being less efficient in ATP production, glycolysis provides carbon moieties needed for biosynthesis of nucleotides, amino acids, and lipids, supporting rapid proliferation and cellular maintenance.

questions.text: An epileptic patient presents with gum hypertrophy and bleeding. Which antiepileptic drug is the likely cause? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phenytoin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Phenytoin is known to cause gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) and bleeding as adverse effects. The adverse effects of phenytoin can be remembered using the mnemonic
  • • "HOT MALIKA":
  • • "HOT MALIKA":
  • • H : Hirsutism and Hypertrophy of gums
  • • H
  • • O : Osteomalacia
  • • O
  • • T : Teratogenicity (fetal hydantoin syndrome)
  • • T
  • • M : Megaloblastic anemia (due to folate deficiency)
  • • M
  • • A : Arrhythmias (in overdose)
  • • A
  • • L : Lymph node enlargement (lymphadenopathy)
  • • L
  • • I : Inhibition of insulin secretion (can lead to hyperglycemia)
  • • I
  • • K : Vitamin K deficiency (can result in bleeding)
  • • K
  • • A : Ataxia, nystagmus, vertigo (cerebellar side effects in overdose)
  • • A
  • • The gum hypertrophy is a direct effect of phenytoin on gingival tissue, while the bleeding is due to vitamin K deficiency caused by phenytoin.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Valproate:
  • • Option B. Valproate:
  • • Valproate's adverse effects include
  • • V - Vomiting
  • • V
  • • A - Alopecia/Curling of hair
  • • A
  • • L - Liver disease (hepatotoxicity: in young children has high incidence)
  • • L
  • • P - Pancreatitis, ↑ risk of PCOD (gender Specific S/E)
  • • P
  • • R - Rash, allergy
  • • R
  • • O - Obesity
  • • O
  • • A - Ataxia (in overdose)
  • • A
  • • TE - Teratogenicity (most teratogenic Antiepileptic drug)
  • • TE
  • • Therefore, if administered during pregnancy, a high dose of folic acid (4000μg/day) should be supplemented to prevent neural tube defects.
  • • Therefore, if administered during pregnancy, a high dose of folic acid (4000μg/day) should be supplemented to prevent neural tube defects.
  • • Option C. Carbamazepine:
  • • Option C. Carbamazepine:
  • • Carbamazepine's adverse effects can be remembered as "4 A's":
  • • Carbamazepine's adverse effects can be remembered as "4 A's":
  • • Auto -induction (increases metabolism of itself and other drugs) Aplastic anemia (bone marrow suppression) ADH release (which can cause SIADH and dilutional hyponatremia) Ataxia /nystagmus/vertigo (in overdose)
  • • Auto -induction (increases metabolism of itself and other drugs)
  • • Auto

  • • Aplastic
  • • ADH release (which can cause SIADH and dilutional hyponatremia)
  • • ADH
  • • Ataxia /nystagmus/vertigo (in overdose)
  • • Ataxia
  • • It does not cause gum hypertrophy or vitamin K deficiency leading to bleeding.
  • • It does not cause gum hypertrophy or vitamin K deficiency leading to bleeding.
  • • Option D. Ethosuximide: Ethosuximide primarily affects T-type calcium channels and is used mainly for absence seizures. Its adverse effects are relatively mild compared to other antiepileptics and do not include gum hypertrophy or bleeding. The main side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances and CNS effects.
  • • Option D. Ethosuximide:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phenytoin causes gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) and vitamin K deficiency leading to bleeding as characteristic adverse effects, which can be remembered using the mnemonic
  • ➤ "HOT MALIKA."
  • ➤ "HOT MALIKA."

questions.text: Post-partum IUCD insertion can be inserted till? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 48h

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postpartum IUCD can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery or after six weeks postpartum . The period between 48 hours and six weeks is contraindicated for IUCD insertion.
  • ➤ within 48 hours of delivery or after six weeks postpartum

questions.text: What renal function does the formula UV/P represent? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Clearance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The formula UV/P is used to calculate the renal clearance of a substance, reflecting the volume of plasma from which the kidneys can completely remove that substance per unit time.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used as nail lacquer belongs to morpholines? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Amorolfine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A morolfine is the only morpholine derivative , used as a nail lacquer for the treatment of fungal infections .
  • ➤ morolfine
  • ➤ morpholine derivative
  • ➤ nail lacquer
  • ➤ fungal infections

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Circumvallate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Circumvallate papilla are located on the dorsum of the tongue, forming a V-shaped row in front of the terminal sulcus (the V-shaped groove that separates the anterior two-thirds from the posterior third of the tongue). They are the largest papillae, about 8-12 in number, and have a round, raised shape. Each is surrounded by a trench (or moat), hence the name 'circumvallate.

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department with multiple injuries, which included a femur fracture as well. He developed confusion, dyspnea, and a rash over his body. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fat embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with fracture of femur, complaint of breathlessness after 48 hours, is highly suggestive of fat embolism.

questions.text: A patient presents with complains of numbness, tingling, and paresthesia in the lateral three and a half fingers, along with numbness at the base of the thumb. Which nerve is most commonly affected in this case? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Median nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The median nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral three and a half fingers on the palmar side and the base of the thumb . Compression of the median nerve at the wrist (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome ) leads to numbness, tingling, and paresthesia in the affected digits without dorsal hand involvement.
  • ➤ median nerve
  • ➤ sensory innervation
  • ➤ lateral three and a half fingers
  • ➤ base of the thumb
  • ➤ median nerve at the wrist
  • ➤ carpal tunnel syndrome
  • ➤ numbness, tingling, and paresthesia

questions.text: An octogenarian female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing imaging studies, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a sizable stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that allows for the visualization and management of bile duct stones. It is particularly useful when there is a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). ERCP can be used to remove or extract stones from the common bile duct and may also involve the placement of a stent to relieve biliary obstruction if necessary.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) may be considered as a subsequent procedure, but it is usually not the initial step in patients with impacted stones in the gallbladder and CBD stones. ERCP is performed first to address the CBD stone and relieve any associated biliary obstruction.
  • • Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy:
  • • Option C. Wait and watch: Waiting and watching may not be appropriate in this case because the patient is symptomatic with constant fatigue, which can be related to biliary obstruction. Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications.
  • • Option C. Wait and watch:
  • • Option D. CT scan: A CT scan may have been done as part of the initial imaging studies to assess the condition, but it is not the definitive treatment for gallbladder and CBD stones. The primary treatment should focus on relieving the obstruction caused by the CBD stone.
  • • Option D. CT scan:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the preferred initial treatment for patients with common bile duct stones and biliary obstruction, as it allows for both diagnosis and therapeutic intervention, such as stone removal and stent placement.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. He has a retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise. There is no mucosal bleeding in the patient. Which of the following coagulation factor can be responsible for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Factor 8/9 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemophilia, caused by deficiencies in factors VIII or IX, presents with recurrent deep tissue bleeding and hemarthrosis, without significant mucosal bleeding. This differentiates it from other bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: A boys' hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Isolate for 6 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 72 hours of exposure

options.label: B
options.text: Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Isolate for 6 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For managing a chickenpox outbreak in a boys' hostel, the best step is to isolate affected individuals for 6 days from the onset of the rash. This helps prevent the spread of the virus. Antiviral treatments and immunoglobulins are reserved for high-risk individuals.
  • ➤ isolate affected individuals for 6 days

questions.text: Leading questions can be allowed in? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cross Examination

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Leading questions (questions whose answers can be given in yes/no format) are specifically allowed in:
  • • Cross examination Dying deposition For example: "Has Ram killed Shyam?" is a leading question, while "Who killed Shyam?" is not This restriction helps ensure unbiased testimony during direct examination and re-examination​
  • • Cross examination
  • • Dying deposition For example: "Has Ram killed Shyam?" is a leading question, while "Who killed Shyam?" is not This restriction helps ensure unbiased testimony during direct examination and re-examination​
  • • For example:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Direct Examination: Incorrect. Leading questions are not allowed in direct examination unless a witness becomes hostile
  • • Option A. Direct Examination: Incorrect.
  • • not allowed
  • • a witness becomes hostile
  • • ​
  • • Option C. Re-Direct Examination: Incorrect. Leading questions are not permitted unless required to clarify contradictions arising from cross-examination​
  • • Option C. Re-Direct Examination: Incorrect.
  • • are not permitted
  • • clarify contradictions
  • • Option D. Any Time: Incorrect. Leading questions are not allowed freely in all legal proceedings. They are only allowed in cross-examination and dying depositions ​
  • • Option D. Any Time: Incorrect.
  • • not allowed freely
  • • only allowed in cross-examination
  • • dying depositions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leading questions
  • ➤ Leading questions
  • ➤ Ans can be given in Yes/ No E.g., Has Suresh killed Madan? – is a leading question Who killed Madan? - It is not a leading question
  • ➤ Leading Questions
  • ➤ Leading Questions
  • ➤ When leading conditions can be asked
  • ➤ When leading conditions can be asked
  • ➤ Dying deposition Cross examination As an exception in Examination in chief if witness turns hostile
  • ➤ Dying deposition
  • ➤ Cross examination
  • ➤ As an exception in Examination in chief if witness turns hostile
  • ➤ When leading questions cannot be asked
  • ➤ When leading questions cannot be asked
  • ➤ Dying declaration Examination in chief Re – examination
  • ➤ Dying declaration
  • ➤ Examination in chief
  • ➤ Re – examination

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blastocyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The blastocyst is a key structure in early human development that forms around day 5 post-fertilization and is essential for implantation. It consists of a trophoblast and an inner cell mass, which give rise to the placenta and embryo, respectively.

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Minimal change disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Effacement of podocyte foot processes is the characteristic feature of minimal change disease (MCD), which presents with nephrotic syndrome and shows normal glomeruli on light microscopy but diffuse foot process flattening on electron microscopy.

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.correct_answer: C. CSF PCR for viral DNA
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a rapid and accurate diagnosis of HSV encephalitis, CSF PCR for viral DNA is the gold standard, essential for guiding appropriate antiviral therapy.

questions.text: A truck driver came with painful genital ulcer and lymph nodes. H/O unprotected sex present. Choose the correct clinical condition: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chancroid

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child presented with pharyngitis. A swab was taken from his throat and sent for culture testing. After using the swab, which color-coded bin should it be disposed into? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Yellow

questions.text: An elderly patient complains of multiple clots in his urine. Which catheter should be used in this patient which can facilitate irrigation and clot removal from the urinary bladder? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 22 French Foley's 3 lumen catheter

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A triple lumen catheter is ideal for managing clots in bladder as it has:
  • • First channel for urine drainage Second channel for balloon inflation Third channel specifically for continuous irrigation 22 French size is appropriate for adequate drainage of clots Commonly used after procedures like TURP where post-operative clots are expected Allows simultaneous irrigation and drainage
  • • First channel for urine drainage
  • • Second channel for balloon inflation
  • • Third channel specifically for continuous irrigation
  • • 22 French size is appropriate for adequate drainage of clots
  • • Commonly used after procedures like TURP where post-operative clots are expected
  • • Allows simultaneous irrigation and drainage
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 22 French Foley's 4 lumen catheter - Incorrect
  • • Option A. 22 French Foley's 4 lumen catheter
  • • Does not exist in clinical practice No requirement for fourth lumen
  • • Does not exist in clinical practice
  • • No requirement for fourth lumen
  • • Option C. 22 French Foley's 2 lumen catheter - Incorrect
  • • Option C. 22 French Foley's 2 lumen catheter
  • • Has only drainage and balloon inflation channels No separate channel for irrigation Cannot perform continuous irrigation effectively
  • • Has only drainage and balloon inflation channels
  • • No separate channel for irrigation
  • • Cannot perform continuous irrigation effectively
  • • Option D. 22 French Foley's 1 lumen catheter - Incorrect
  • • Option D. 22 French Foley's 1 lumen catheter
  • • Cannot be self-retaining as no balloon inflation channel No irrigation capability Inadequate for managing clots Not practical for this clinical scenario
  • • Cannot be self-retaining as no balloon inflation channel
  • • No irrigation capability
  • • Inadequate for managing clots
  • • Not practical for this clinical scenario

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A three-way Foley's catheter (22Fr) is the appropriate choice for managing bladder clots as it allows simultaneous drainage and irrigation through separate channels.

questions.text: In an urban area in the state of Madhya Pradesh, a first-time pregnant woman visits a healthcare facility for her delivery following encouragement from an ASHA worker. What monetary advantages will they obtain under the Janani Suraksha Yojana? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.correct_answer: A. 1000 for mother and 400 for ASHA
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1000 for mother and 400 for ASHA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ (LPS: Low performing states; HPS: High performing states)
  • ➤ (LPS include UP, Uttarakhand, MP, Jharkhand, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, Jammu & Kashmir, Rajasthan)

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An abdominal X-ray was done, as shown below. Identify the bowel segment involved? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Jejunum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario and X-ray are suggestive of intestinal obstruction where the involved segment is the jejunum. The obstructed bowel loops are centrally located and have valvulae conniventes (complete mucosal folds), indicating jejunal involvement.
  • • obstructed bowel loops are centrally located and have valvulae conniventes
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option. B. Ileum : Typically, ileal loops are located more peripherally and may show less prominent valvulae conniventes.
  • • Option. B. Ileum
  • • Option. C. Duodenum : Not usually seen as prominently distended in obstructions due to its fixed retroperitoneal location and smaller length.
  • • Option. C. Duodenum
  • • Option. D. Transverse colon : Would generally show haustrations (sacculations) rather than valvulae conniventes, and distension would be more peripherally located.
  • • Option. D. Transverse colon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presented with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. Which one is the most likely primary cause?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Anal cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anal cancer is a primary malignancy associated with the enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes due to its anatomical and lymphatic relationship with the anal canal below the dentate line. Recognizing this link is crucial for correct diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with palpitations, dizziness, and mild shortness of breath. Her ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia with a regular rhythm, consistent with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Her blood pressure is stable. What is the first-line drug of choice for treating this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adenosine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a hemodynamically stable patient with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) , adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment after attempting vagal maneuvers .
  • • hemodynamically stable
  • • supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)
  • • adenosine
  • • first-line pharmacological treatment
  • • vagal maneuvers
  • • Adenosine is preferred because:
  • • Extremely short half-life (8-10 seconds) Effectively terminates most forms of SVT by blocking AV nodal conduction Administered as a rapid IV push (6 mg initial dose, followed by 12 mg if needed)
  • • Extremely short half-life (8-10 seconds)
  • • Extremely short half-life (8-10 seconds)
  • • Effectively terminates most forms of SVT by blocking AV nodal conduction
  • • Effectively terminates most forms of SVT
  • • blocking AV nodal conduction
  • • Administered as a rapid IV push (6 mg initial dose, followed by 12 mg if needed)
  • • Administered as a rapid IV push (6 mg initial dose, followed by 12 mg if needed)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Amiodarone: Not first-line therapy for acute SVT. More commonly used for ventricular arrhythmias or refractory SVT
  • • Option B. Amiodarone:
  • • ventricular arrhythmias or refractory SVT
  • • Option C. Metoprolol: Effective for rate control in AF , but not the first choice for acute SVT termination
  • • Option C. Metoprolol:
  • • AF
  • • not the first choice for acute SVT termination
  • • Option D. Verapamil: Used for SVT treatment , but not first-line due to risk of hypotension and bradycardia
  • • Option D. Verapamil:
  • • SVT treatment
  • • not first-line
  • • risk of hypotension and bradycardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenosine is the first-line treatment for hemodynamically stable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) , administered as a rapid IV push following vagal maneuvers.
  • ➤ Adenosine is the first-line treatment
  • ➤ hemodynamically stable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)
  • ➤ rapid IV push

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with recurrent headaches, visual disturbances, and features of increased intracranial tension. CT imaging reveals a well-circumscribed brain lesion, and its biopsy shows psammoma bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Meningioma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meningiomas are characterized by the presence of psammoma bodies (concentric calcifications) on histopathological examination and typically present as well-circumscribed lesions causing symptoms of increased intracranial pressure.
  • ➤ psammoma bodies
  • ➤ (concentric calcifications)
  • ➤ well-circumscribed

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Selenite F broth is specifically used as an enrichment medium for isolating Shigella from stool samples in cases presenting with symptoms of dysentery, characterized by blood in the stools. This selective medium helps in the effective recovery of pathogens responsible for dysentery, aiding in accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.
  • ➤ Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. They are catalase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods, and are non-motile. It acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It causes acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test .
  • ➤ Dysentery/Shigellosis
  • ➤ acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit
  • ➤ a positive Sereny test

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presented to the clinic and underwent karyotyping. What is the likely diagnosis in the karyotype shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Turner syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45, XO karyotype, where there is a complete or partial absence of the second X chromosome, leading to infertility, primary amenorrhea, and other characteristic features.

questions.text: What is the recommended dose of adrenaline for a child during cardiac arrest ? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 0.01 mg/kg (1ml/kg of 1:10,000 solution)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct dose of adrenaline for a child during cardiac arrest is 0.01 mg/kg using a 1:10,000 solution.

questions.text: According to World Health Organization (WHO), blindness is defined as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) VA < 3/60

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The WHO definition of blindness, adopted since 2017, is visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with best possible correction, or visual field less than 10 degrees, or inability to count fingers at 3 meters.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, the second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and the third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:
  • • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:
  • • The patient's history of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) and a pregnancy complicated by early-onset preeclampsia is highly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA). APLA is diagnosed based on clinical and laboratory criteria. The clinical criteria include obstetric complications such as unexplained fetal death, severe preeclampsia necessitating early delivery, and recurrent early pregnancy losses. Vascular thrombosis is also a clinical criterion. Laboratory criteria include the presence of lupus anticoagulant, medium to high titers of anticardiolipin antibodies, and anti-β2 glycoprotein antibodies. These must be present on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart. The Sapporo Criteria for diagnosing APLA require at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion to be present.
  • • The patient's history of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) and a pregnancy complicated by early-onset preeclampsia is highly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA).
  • • APLA is diagnosed based on clinical and laboratory criteria. The clinical criteria include obstetric complications such as unexplained fetal death, severe preeclampsia necessitating early delivery, and recurrent early pregnancy losses. Vascular thrombosis is also a clinical criterion.
  • • Laboratory criteria include the presence of lupus anticoagulant, medium to high titers of anticardiolipin antibodies, and anti-β2 glycoprotein antibodies. These must be present on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart.
  • • The Sapporo Criteria for diagnosing APLA require at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion to be present.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Syphilis: Although syphilis can cause adverse pregnancy outcomes, including miscarriage and stillbirth, it is less likely than APLA to cause the combination of early pregnancy loss and early-onset preeclampsia described in this case.
  • • Option A. Syphilis:
  • • Option C. TORCH infections: TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other agents, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and Herpes simplex virus) can lead to congenital anomalies, intrauterine growth restriction, and pregnancy loss. However, recurrent pregnancy loss due to TORCH infections is rare.
  • • Option C. TORCH infections:
  • • Option D. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) typically affects pregnancies later in gestation and is associated with macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, and other complications, but it is not commonly associated with recurrent pregnancy loss or early-onset preeclampsia.
  • • Option D. Gestational diabetes mellitus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss and complications such as early-onset preeclampsia, necessitating early delivery. Diagnosis is based on the presence of clinical and laboratory criteria according to the Sapporo Criteria.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2550, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2550, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 38-year-old female who is experiencing substantial hair loss for 4 months and has a history of COVID-19 infection 8 months ago? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telogen effluvium is a form of non-scarring hair loss characterized by the diffuse shedding of hair resulting from the early entry of hair into the telogen phase (the resting phase of the hair cycle). This condition is often triggered by significant physiological stress, severe illness, or major life events.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9 th Edition Chapter 89 page no 32.24, 32.39, 32.40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20 89.24, 89.25, 89.46
  • ↳ Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9 th edition page 1509
  • ↳ Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9 th edition page 1509
  • ↳ Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21 st edition 387
  • ↳ Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21 st edition 387

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital for a follow-up after undergoing a total thyroidectomy. He reports experiencing perioral numbness that started three days after the surgery. Upon further investigation, the patient has no history of nerve damage, facial trauma, or dental procedures. What diagnostic tests should be conducted to determine the cause of the perioral numbness? NEET PG 2022
questions.correct_answer: D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands. It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.
  • ➤ Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands.
  • ➤ It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been diagnosed with achalasia cardia through esophageal manometry. The manometry results reveal simultaneous, high-pressure contractions in the distal esophagus, along with spasmodic contractions. What type of achalasia does this patient's presentation correspond among the provided options?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Type III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type III achalasia, also known as spastic achalasia, involves spastic contractions in the distal esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax. This type is the least common and often requires more aggressive therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is contra-indicated in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Enalapril

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors and ARBs are absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy as they cause fetal renal hypoplasia/agenesis leading to oligohydramnios.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement about a patient with a retroperitoneal mass, episodic hypertension, palpitations, and increased urinary VMA levels? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: It can be associated with MEN 2A

questions.correct_answer: D. It can be associated with MEN 2A
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It can be associated with MEN 2A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pheochromocytomas are catecholamine-secreting tumors associated with episodic hypertension and increased urinary VMA levels. They are commonly linked with MEN 2A syndrome, which involves RET gene mutations.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest time when triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC) staining can detect changes after a myocardial infarction? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2-3 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) staining can detect myocardial infarction changes as early as 2-3 hours post-infarction by identifying areas where LDH enzyme has leaked from damaged cardiac cells.
  • ➤ Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC)

questions.text: A 20-year-old male complained of gradual swelling around the wrist for 3 months. X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Giant cell tumor

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman underwent hip replacement surgery. A week after the surgery, the patient developed swelling of the legs associated with pain on palpation. Her heart rate is 70 beats per min. There is no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. What is the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient based on Well's score? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. High

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When assessing the risk of pulmonary embolism, especially in postoperative patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of DVT, it is essential to consider both the clinical presentation and the surgical history. The Wells score is a valuable tool in stratifying the risk and guiding further diagnostic testing and management. In this scenario, the patient falls into a high-risk category, indicating that further immediate investigation, typically with imaging like a CT pulmonary angiogram, is warranted.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - UpToDate/Wells score

questions.text: An individual went to the US and developed an infection. LPCB mount showed the following. Identify the cause. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Histoplasma capsulatum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histoplasma capsulatum is identified by its distinctive tuberculate macroconidia on LPCB mounts, which is a key feature to recognize this dimorphic fungus, especially in infections contracted in the United States.

questions.text: To study the effect of Vitamin C consumption on the occurrence of Respiratory disease, arrange the steps of a case-control study in sequence. (NEET PG 2024) 1 – Measurement of exposure. 2 – Matching. 3 – Analysis and interpretation. 4 – Selection of cases and controls.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 4-2-1-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of steps in a case-control study is: Selection of cases and controls, matching, measurement of exposure, and then analysis and interpretation.
